transportAdvice: Raja Ampat has no public transit system; travel between islands is almost entirely by speedboat or traditional wooden longboat, with most resorts and guesthouses arranging transfers for guests. Walking is limited to individual islands, and private boat hire is the standard way to explore the archipelago.

weather.description: Peak wet season with frequent heavy downpours and rough seas, making some dive sites and inter-island travel more challenging.
Continued wet season with persistent rain and choppy waters, though diving remains possible on sheltered sites.
Rain begins to ease slightly toward month's end but seas can still be unsettled and humidity remains high.
Transitional month with decreasing rainfall and improving sea conditions as the dry season approaches.
Conditions improve noticeably with calmer seas and good underwater visibility, marking the start of the better diving season.
Dry season begins in earnest with calm seas, excellent visibility, and reliable sunshine ideal for snorkeling and diving.
One of the best months to visit with clear skies, calm waters, and peak marine biodiversity including manta ray sightings.
Excellent dry season conditions continue with superb diving, calm inter-island travel, and comfortable temperatures.
Still within the prime dry season window with outstanding underwater visibility and minimal rainfall.
Transitional period as the wet season approaches; conditions remain largely favorable but occasional showers return.
Rainfall increases and seas begin to roughen, though diving is still rewarding and crowds are thinner.
Wet season returns with heavy rain and swelling seas; some remote sites become inaccessible but sheltered reefs remain diveable.
